There was once a gentle time</br>Whenne the world was in its prime;</br>And everie day was holydaye,</br>And everie monthe was lovelie Maye.—</br>Cupide thenne hadde but to goe</br>With his purple winges and bowe;</br>And in blossomede vale and grove</br>Everie shepherde knelte to Love.

Thenne a rosie, dimplede cheeke,</br>And a blue eye fonde and meeke;</br>And a ringlette-wreathenne browe,</br>Like hyacynthes on a bed of snowe;</br>And a lowe voice silverre sweete</br>From a lippe without deceite:</br>Onlie those the heartes coulde move</br>Of the simple swaines to love.

But thatte time is gone and paste;</br>Canne the summerre alwayes laste!</br>And the swaines are wiser growne,</br>And the hearte is turnede to stone,</br>And the maidenne's rose may witherre,</br>Cupide's fled, no manne knowes whitherre!

But anotherre Cupide's come,</br>With a browe of care and gloome;</br>Fixede upon the earthlie moulde,</br>Thinkinge of the sullenne golde:</br>In his hande the bowe no more,</br>At his backe the householde store,</br>That the bridalle colde muste buye;</br>Uselesse nowe the smile ande sighe:</br>But he weares the pinion stille,</br>Flyinge at the sighte of ille.</br>Oh, for the olde true-love time,</br>Whenne the worlde was in its prime!</br>
